This combination allows two variants: MH# and H$. From the surface tones, there is no way to tell which one is illustrated by this token, since both MH# and H$ yield a surface-phonological M.M+H string when the copula is added.

This combination allows two variants: H# and H$. From the surface tones, there is no way to tell which one is illustrated by this token, since both H# and H$ yield a surface-phonological M.H string. ‡MH# is not an acceptable variant.

The demonstrative's rhyme is mispronounced as [v̩˧]: this is a form of interference with the second syllable, which is in focus and hence the object of more attention on the part of the speaker.
Input tones: tone of the demonstrative, and tone of the classifier (separated by a space): H L2
Output tone: H#
The demonstrative's rhyme is mispronounced as [v̩˧]: this is a form of interference with the second syllable, which is in focus and hence the object of more attention on the part of the speaker.
Input tones: tone of the demonstrative, and tone of the classifier (separated by a space): H L2
Output tone: H#

The demonstrative's initial is mispronounced as [ʈ] instead of [t]: this is a form of interference with the second syllable, which is in focus and hence the object of more attention on the part of the speaker.
Input tones: tone of the demonstrative, and tone of the classifier (separated by a space): H L2
Output tone: MH#

This combination allows two variants: MH# and H$. The variant illustrated by this token could be either of the two, as they yield the same result when in association with the copula.

Input tones: tone of the noun, the demonstrative, and the classifier (separated by spaces): LM H L2
Output tone: L.M.H (LM+H#)
The output tone for the entire group is: LM+H#, hence /æ˩ tʰv̩˧-mi˥ ɲi˩/ when in association with the copula.
